reviewText: In the Electric Mist marks legendary French filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier's first North American-made motion picture and, based on the troubles he encountered while making it, perhaps his last. Tavernier, a big fan of American crime fiction (he previously adapted Jim Thompson's Pop. 1280 into Coup de Torchon - Criterion Collection), jumped at the chance to bring James Lee Burke's bestselling novel In the Electric Mist with Confederate Dead to the big screen. However, reports surfaced that Tavernier and the film's star, Tommy Lee Jones, did not get along, and the producers were not happy with the director's version. As a result, the version released on DVD in North America is the producers' cut and not Tavernier's. Tavernier does an excellent job capturing the local color of the area in the scenes where protagonist Dave Robicheaux (Tommy Lee Jones) canvases the locals. The entire film was shot on location and this only enhances the authenticity of the story's setting which is rich in atmosphere - also helped by the liberal use of blues and zydeco music. The cinematography has a textured quality to it that really brings out the lushness of the region. The cast is outstanding with Tommy Lee Jones doing his patented gruff yet savvy lawman, Peter Sarsgaard portraying a boozy actor, and John Goodman as a scene-stealing mobster with a genial facade that barely masks a threatening demeanor. The cast is rounded out by fascinating veteran character actors like Mary Steenburgen, Pruitt Taylor Vince and Ned Beatty. Despite the production and post-production problems that plagued the film, this version is engaging and entertaining but one still wonders what Tavernier's original cut is like. Sadly, the only special features are a theatrical trailer but considering the bad blood between director and the producers this is hardly suprising.

Buyers beware...

From the opening soliloquy admitting an alcoholic's obsession, to its conclusion in the sweltering bayou, this film version captures everything that has made millions of devoted fans for James Lee Burke's Dave Robicheax novels.  Tommie Lee Jones inhabits the soul Robicheax, a good man of faith haunted by a past of violence, racism and alcohol.  He fights his demons, but it is not clear whether he is winning his fights.

The film drips with bayou heat and rumbling thunderstorms that summon the Confederate Dead from the Electric Mist.  Faulkner wrote of the south that "the past is not dead, its not even the past"  Such is true of Burke' characters, who live in a world of corruption, decption and power, trying to hide from their past, which always in one way or another, finds them.

Who did it?  In one way or another, they all did.  In Dave Robicheax's world, no one is innocent, except maybe those who become victims.

This is an outstanding movie that should have gone into theaters before going to DVD.  But we are fortunate this movie was made, and can only hope that despite whatever contract/production issues led to the movie going to DVD, that we'll see Tommie Lee Jones again as Dave Robicheaux.

I found it difficult to initially write a balanced review on ItEM because I felt so connected to this film. To disclaim, I performed Civil War re-enacting for 8 years with the 5th Texas, and my family name matches the main character; Never have seen Robicheaux/Robechaud in any film. So that aside, I just watched a great Tommie Lee Jones film filled with Civil War history (including a great role by Levon Helm playing John Bell Hood) and modern bayou mystery. Also nice to see the Louisiana area get some film money injected into their economy.

Plenty of upset people out there about the loss from the book series to film, but since I had not read any of the books, and I appreciate a film that doesn't spell every character out for you - this made for a solid, low-key suspense crime saga. Yes, there is a plethora of characters that pop in and out, obvious story lines not being conveyed in their entire sequence, and personality traits never explained with TLJ's violent/subdued split angles - but it all made (wholeheartedly) for a rewatchable film. Believable performances all around, and I hope to see them all again in more of these (like the successful Jesse Stone/Tom Selleck series). Nitpicking aside from other posters (Yes - there was Texas Cavalry in the Civil War) and the film being too short (I look forward to the other films being made), I hope people give this film a chance.

The BD sound was excellent with the DTS, and some of the pans will test your display refresh rate (several sequences of low angles/pointing up with sky backdrops; vehicles driving along ridges, fan boats skimming along the bayou, etc.). Some of the music mix sounded perfect and the 1080p shows our flawed characters' shortcomings in ways I never imagined, including John Goodman in tight swim trunks. There are absolutely no extras to speak of so I could not say this is a 5 star BD release, but definitely worth the purchase.

I am a huge fan of James Lee Burke's Dave Robicheaux books.  I have read most of them and most of them have been top notch.  Unlike most series, Burke's actually gets better and better and just when you think its peaked, he writes something better.

Having read so many of the books, I always pictured either Harrison Ford, Alec Baldwin (in his younger, lighter days) and Tommy Lee Jones as Dave.  2/3 predictions have come true.  Tommy Lee Jones is the perfect David Robicheaux, this character was meant for him to play.

In the Electric Mist is one of the best books in the series, so how come with a great book and great casting the movie is only ok?

The problem is the movie itself is very very inside.  The screen writers did too good a job adapting the story from the book.  Remember the book is a middle book of a very long running series.  As a fan and reader of the series, I knew who everyone was and how they got there.  The problem for the mass audience will be that they will have no idea who half the people are and the film does not really give any answers.

This unfortunately will be a film liked by those who have read the books, and not fully understood by those who have not.

Twice filmakers have well casted and made well intentioned adaptations of the books, and twice they have not come through as they should have.

How did they do this?

Imagine James Lee Burke's dry alcoholic cop Dave Robicheaux played by Tommy Lee Jones. A genius stroke of casting. Nobody else could have done this like TLJ.

Imagine one of JLB's colourful Louisiana crime stories with Blues and Cajuns and a legacy of racism and of decadent rich families with French names and a serial killer who likes to cut up prostitutes, and in all this Dave R. who keeps forgetting that he shouldn't beat up his witnesses.

Imagine the beautiful post Katrina rainy Louisiana countryside shot by professional camera teams.

Imagine a marvellous soundtrack mixing Cajun music and Blues, with Buddy Guy as resident musician. (How come I see and hear him in 2 films within a few weeks? First was Shine a Light, where he was a guest of the Stones.)

So, put all this together, and what is it that you ought to get? Yes, a great thriller full of suspense and visual as well as audio delight.
But what do you get? A perfect bore that fails even to try to interest you in its whodunnits and that never creates a fraction of the sense of danger that the book does, not even when the cop's daughter gets kidnapped by the serial killer. That is no mean feat.
How could you guys foul this up so badly with such a good hand?

I will admit that I am a fan of serial killer books and films.  I will also admit, however, that I usually only like true stories, and I don't believe that this could be a true story, or even "based upon a true story," or even the lesser "inspired by a true story," as it seems fairly fake.  I will finally admit that I didn't watch all of this movie; I turned it off after about the first half hour or so.  So, my two-star rating, I suppose, might have to be taken with a grain of salt.  Kind of like the writing and (some) of the acting in "In the Electric Mist."

First of all, the music is grating.  I hate it when the soundtrack of a film overdoes it by trying to play with your emotions, and this one is certainly guilty of that.  This in itself is almost enough to give this movie a pass.

But it also is the case that almost every film that I've ever screened that is shot in Louisiana, in "The Bayou," is a fail as well.  There are a few exceptions; "Heaven's Prisoners" wasn't completely bad, but probably only because the very fine Teri Hatcher was "nice enough" to walk around naked on screen.  That was enough to make that film watchable.  Hey, I'm a dude, I'm not gay, and I'm mostly honest, so there you go.  (Even the much-missed Roger Ebert once asked his co-host Gene Siskel, "You know what I liked about 'Catwoman'?  Halle Barry's face, Halle Barry's costume, and Halle Barry's body."  He certainly had a point.). But usually, in these southern-fried movies, the writing and acting comes across as clichd, and I would say that this film is no exception.

And this is too bad because, as you already know, Tommy Lee Jones is one of our finest actors.  Usually, when he's just in a movie, you know that it should be good.  I've always thought that great actors only choose great roles with great writing and great direction, and this almost always holds.  But to be honest, once again, he is getting older -- we all do, at the same rate, at least on Earth -- so it just might be the case that he no longer has the clout to pick and choose.  If this is true, it is too bad.

It looks like this film was a Direct-2-DVD affair, and it probably deserves it.  And it also probably deserves a dissing from me, since after all, I am a fan of the genre but found this film almost unwatchable.  Oh, that's right; it was unwatchable.  I turned it off early in the second act, and I'm pretty sure that not much was missed.

IN THE ELECTRIC MIST, (In the Electric Mist with Confederate Dead), (2008). This 102 minute thriller, helmed by the well-thought of French director Bertrand Tavernier, (Round Midnight) centers on characters created by beloved, bestselling American author of crime dramas, James Lee Burke. The mystery is set in and around New Orleans, Burke's home, French-speaking turf, after the terrible damage inflicted on the region in 2005 by Hurricane Katrina. Principally, it tells us of troubled former New Orleans Police Detective Dave Robicheaux, now a deputy sheriff in neighboring Iberia County. The lead part is fully inhabited by veteran Texas-born actor Tommy Lee Jones, (Men In Black,The Fugitive), who might well have been born to play it, as it was created by the Texas Panhandle-born Burke. The stubborn Robichaux, haunted by his service in the Vietnam War, struggling with a drinking problem, is, as ever, ignoring warnings to leave the local messes alone. He begins to investigate the possible connections between a series of torture murders of local prostitutes, a 1976 lynching that he witnessed 35 years before as a young boy, and Julie `Baby Feet' Balboni, a notorious New Orleans gangster, played by the popular St. Louis-born John Goodman,(The Big Easy). The Southern-born Mary Steenburgen, (Cross Creek), plays Bootsie, the detective's second wife. Peter Sarsgaard, (Year of the Dog), plays actor Elrod Sykes, filming locally; Kelly Macdonald, (Intermission), is Sykes' girlfriend Kelly Drummond. Ned Beatty, (Hear My Song) plays local rich man/bad guy Twinky LeMoyne. Noted American musician Levon Helm plays long-dead General John Bell Hood, a Civil War stalwart who suddenly starts appearing to and chatting with Robicheaux and Sykes. Noted American bluesman Buddy Guy plays local bluesman Sam `Hogman' Patin. Director John Sayles plays Michael Goldman, producer of the picture filming locally. Marco Beltrami created the evocative score; Bruno de Keyzer, the cinematography. The plot sticks recognizably close to Burke's underlying novel of the same name,In the Electric Mist with Confederate Dead . Jones nails the part of Burke's detective, giving us a rounded performance that shows the complex nature of the character, violent one minute, tender the next. He is miles better than Alec Baldwin, who was laughably miscast as the detective in HEAVENS PRISONERS. And it's not a bad movie. Yet, my understanding is that, although this film was made for theatrical release, it eventually went directly to DVD, which is probably why I, for one, although I am a Burke fan, never knew of its existence until I was informed of it by my Amazon friends. I think some major structural problems may have caused that outcome. Any Burke fan will know the detective's best friend, another former NOPD detective, Clete Purcel, overweight, sunburnt, heavy drinker, violent, everlastingly loyal, also native to NO's Irish Channel. Therefore, any Burke fan who has been to the movies a few times, in seeing the cast list before seeing the picture, will expect that Ned Beatty is playing Purcel. I did. But, somehow, the Purcel character isn't there, and Beatty is playing one of the heavies. Also, Goodman has long been associated with The Big Easy, and it was perfectly reasonable to cast him as the gangster in this gritty film. But Goodman, I believe, is a popular actor, and I suspect people may be uncomfortable with the way he is here treated. I was. Both these misjudgments create a film that's disappointing, but I still enjoyed it, as most Burke fans might.

So from reading other reviews I gather this is a book loosely based on a series of books. Tommy Lee Jones was unconvincing in the lead role being noticeably aged since the last time I watched one of his films.  The actor's age and noticeable limp/stiff leg walk made him look ancient for the role.  The character's frequent too easily executed roughing up of everyone from mafia-like heavies to random street hoods begged the question how the character had made it this far in his career without being whacked before now.  Other characters were one-dimensional, notably the drunk hollywood moviestar and his girlfriend (straight out of Agatha Christie!), John Goodman as the mafia-like boss, and numerous others.  The FBI detective was bizarrely deferential to the main detective character, responding to all blatant acts of aggression and illegality with a tut-and-shake-of-the-head motion, perhaps a look of slight bafflement and then acting like nothing had happened.

The plot itself was mystifying, with numerous threads that the Tommy Lee Jones' main character conveniently linked together in a series of baffling hunches that always worked out.  In other places there were holes big enough to drive a tank through.  For all of the "series of grisly murders" referred to in the description of this movie none of the victims are developed in any way.  The FBI-referenced history of serial killing is limited to just that, a reference, with no development or expansion into why the FBI are even really involved (The agent certainly doesn't add anything to the investigation).  The whole movie descends into nothing more than an examination of the main character's virtues and attempts to get to the truth.  And when we get into the 'ghosts' that appear in the middle of the story, it just becomes totally unbelievable.  As the plot wraps up, loose ends are brushed aside, leads left untapped, and questions left unanswered.  And for those who have seen the movie, can anyone explain why the daughter character says "Dave?" while looking a picture of John Bell Hood right before the credits roll?  That resulted in popcorn being thrown at the TV!

All in all, there was potential here, but terrible casting, execution, one-dimensional characters and a half-baked story line make this entirely missable.

Interesting adaptation of the James Lee Burke novel by the fine French director Bernard Tavernier, starring Tommy Lee Jones. Main problem is the script, which is fairly incoherent -- but then so was the novel. Most interesting thing about Burke's novels is the interior monologue of the main character, Dave Robicheaux -- the action mainly serves as a catalyst for Robicheaux's commentary. In the movie there's minimal voice-over, which ain't the same. One objection: Robicheaux is slipped some LSD in his iced tea and ends up in the hospital after running his truck into a (shallow) ditch and hallucinating up a storm. The hallucinations, and succeeding flashbacks, involve a philosophical dialogue with a dead Civil War general, who'd fought in the area 100 years before. Sorry, Hollywood: those ain't like any LSD hallucinations I ever experienced -- too clean, to coherent. Tavernier does his best with a weak script (& his work is always worth watching -- see "Round Midnight" as the best example). And Tommy Lee Jones is probably the best Dave Robicheaux we can expect. I had hoped for more, but it appears Burke is as hard to adapt as Richard Stark (Payback, Point Blank, The Outfit).

Louisiana is truly a star of this piece, and the scenery alone makes you homesick for a place you may never have been.

The script, dealing with the murders of young women, is not so much driven by a frantic effort to save as the need to overcome evil and provide justice.

Yes, few car chases here and the violence is largely viewed as aftermath.  But I found that I cared about all the characters, and wanted to know what would happen next.

Don't try to "half-way" watch this film.  Give it your full attention, or don't bother.  It is as much a moral and human drama as a crime story.

Tommy Lee Jones is his usual prepared, talented self in this multiple murder mystery set in post-Katrina New Orleans.  His characterization of dedicated police officer Dave Robicheaux, putting together the pieces of the complicated puzzle which comprises a series of prostitute murders reaching far back into the seemingly unrelated fabric of New Orleans' complicated racist past, while confronting the personal demons recovering alcoholics must face, is believable, many-layered, and sensitive to both sides of the Deep South's troubled, segregationist history.  Credit must also be given to the director and editor for their handling of a series of hallucinatory encounters between Robicheaux and Confederate General John Bell Hood (Levon Helm) after the detective is given a drink laced with LSD.  These scenes could have easily tossed the film into the nether world of unbelievability, but cast and crew handle the difficult task of making these scenes ring true, bringing them surreally to life within the film's plot line and toward its dark conclusion.  Other cast standouts include veteran screen presence Mary Steenburgen--a welcome addition to any film--as his loyal and supportive wife, Peter Sarsgaard as the on-location film star dealing with his own "battle of the bottle," Ned Beatty as influential businessman Twinky Le Moyne, who appears genuinely, though minimally, remorseful for his role in an ancient, apparently Klan-related murder, and especially long-time New Orleans resident John Goodman as the cynical, racketeer-with-a-punch-line, Julie "Baby Feet" Balboni, who as journeyman performer has become one of America's most impressive and reliable character actors.  Also watch for famed indie director John Sayles' portrayal of the--what else?--director of the partially mob-produced film around which the plot for IN THE ELECTRIC MIST is set.

  novel of greed, revenge  and  redemption, that  involve  Detective
  Robicheaux  having  conversations with a  REAL  Confederate  General !

  In the novel, Robicheaux is  guided,  morally, by this phantasm.

  Tommy  Lee  Jones  is  hugely  miscast as  Dave Robicheaux, a  New Iberia
  Parish,  Louisiana  Sheriff's  Department  Detective.

  Jones  has  the weathered  look  of  age  and crepitude  of  the
  Robicheaux  we've  read  about  in  Burke's  many  novels,  but
  Jones'  interpretation  of  our ( unlikely) hero,  is  shallow, and
  pseudo - gritty.

  This  Robicheaux is  "Robicheaux  Lite".  Jones  plays a  depthless,
  one-dimensional  guy  who  is  just  lost in a  booze-laden  dream-
  world.

  The  real  Robicheaux,  is a  recovering  alcoholic,  hard-working,
  sensitive, loving,  with an  adopted  daughter,  and  a  second  wife,
  a  former  nun,  who is  long-suffering,  and  is a  "stand-by-your-
  man"  kind  of  a  girl.

  Tavernier's  rocket  fails  to  ignite  at  the  lunch  pad,  folks.

  BOOK, professionally  read by Mister  Will Patton.

  The  audio  book  is  FIVE  STARS  OUT OF  FIVE.

  I  can  think of  about  twenty  directors  who  would  have  given

As has been so well commented upon by some other reviewers, this movie is soooooo faithful (and appropriately so) to Burke's novel and his characters, as well as his hero's (?) always so justified outrage and railing at the morally corrupt, who ALWAYS just happen to be wealthy!  Sort of suggests that Burke is setting up straw men in order to express his hostility to authority and the wealth of others, doesn't it?  Nevertheless, I love his so expressive and (if you could call it that given his profane brutality) elegant narrative!  And this is so well carried over into this movie, both the elegance and the profane brutality.  As you can tell, I loved the book, and I loved the movie.

As has also been commented here, the movie suffers greatly, as a stand alone piece, through the total absence of introducing the characters (Bootsie, Tripod, etc) to the viewer who is not familiar with his writing - the family members and other important characters simply appear!  I intend recommending this to others, but only (if they are interested) if I have an opportunity to give them an introduction.

I have read several novels by James Lee Burke; none were especially good, but rather average--in its own way average is a compliment since most novels, mystery or otherwise, are really mediocre, if not just plain execrable. This movie is lifted with almost complete fidelity from his novel and the movie suffers from a stasis in which the plot moves forward not at all or slowly. Tommy Lee Jones acts as if his questionable charisma is all that is needed to make a film work well. The lack of any forward propulsion of the plot in many scenes in the movie is frustrating for the viewer. The first half-hour, which should "hook" us into watching the film, is a non-starter: slow and boring. Back to Jones for one final comment: he has acted well in some movies, most particularly No Country For Old Men. But in this film he has a solid and credible context in which to act out his character. It doesn't hurt that this film is very good, largely because it is faithfully based on a novel by the profoundly good novelist Cormac MacCarthy.
  Ultimately, a movie must be judged by narrative success (a movie is not a static painting or sculpture).  In this regard, the movie must inexorably be judged a failure. It is shallow and will
disappoint viewers who want to be drawn into a movie that has something to say.

Here's the scoop. Set in Louisiana, Tommy Lee plays a police captain who is ready to bust Sarsgaard, a Hollywood actor in town for a film shoot, on a DUI. To avoid said DUI Peter leads Tommy to an area of the swamp where he spotted a corpse shackled in chains. Even though the body has been dead since the 60s Tommy wants to investigate. Meanwhile, a young prostitute from town is murdered and Tommy wants to make the connection between the two which leads him to investigate all manner of unseemly persons.

Nearly every scene in this movie was written and acted extremely well. A lot of really cool things happened in the plotting. Most of the characters, even the secondary ones, had a lot of personality, but it all failed to dovetail. Like the dead guy in chains. He's what started the whole thing off but very little is done in regard to that part of the story. And it didn't build up tension. It kept a generally even keel throughout. This might be truer to how real life is but it doesn't make for exciting movies.

Let's say that the story moves along with a sense of stately grace perfectly at home with the Old South themes and settings.

The cast is outstanding. Tommy Lee Jones and John Goodman pick up any film, and Peter Sarsgaard does a masterful job as the rich, alcoholic film actor with an irrepressible enthusiasm and absolutely no clue just how dangerous his behavior is.

The movie is gritty and sordid at times. Even if the worst visuals stay a good bit shy of what other films might try to gross you out with, here they make sure that the dialog fills you in on anything they may have spared your eyes. The reaction of the man who swears off ever looking into a mysterious barrel again is real, and chilling, for example.

I wasn't expecting a whole lot out of this film- I can often take or leave Tommy Lee Jones, as he so often plays the gruff-yet-philosophical-Southerner type and could almost be accused of the Robin WIlliams syndrome- too many of the same sort of roles (tho Robin has busted right out of that prison with a handful of well-done psycho roles). But I remembered why I essentially enjoy him as an actor, because nobody can do the gruff-yet-philosophical number as well as he.

First off, as a Southerner, I was very happy to see some intelligence accorded to the natives. Yeah, there are your usual white trash folk here, but that is a reality- prodigious use of the "n" word, lots of beer drinking and fishing, etc- and to pretend that doesn't exist would be false. But I very much enjoyed both Jones' lyrical way of talking as well as Levon Helm's Civil War general- and I won't say much beyond that lest i give it away. Naturally this is based on a novel so I can only say that the screen adaption has made me mightily curious to read the book, as it has a lot of depth and a surprising amount of heart.

The one flaw the film had was the perplexing use of people who couldn't act in supporting roles. Some of the local types seemed like they were reading off cue cards, and Buddy Guy, bless him, has plenty enough talent without having to prove that he can act, which i am sad to say, he can't. There was also a little bit of an overdose on the folksy wisdom a time or two, but I found most of the film surprising. I was definitely surprised and it exceeded my expectations. I would call this a supernatural mystery, and I wish more of them were set in the bayous- a haunted place if there ever was one.

By the time the film ends you are hoping for some kind of twist or shock ending, but instead you get very little coherence between scarce plot lines and not a great deal left of the story that bears any relation to anything else. There is no real motive or back story to the murderers actions and you are left doubting the credibility of the entire film. As you can see there isn't a great deal to commend this film for and to be honest you can miss this and not worry in the slightest. Watch this if nothing else is on (or buy it if you have money burning a hole in your pocket), but otherwise check out something else to pass your time.

Detective Dave Robicheaux sees the ghosts of Confederate soldiers in the Louisiana mist and thinks he's going crazy.  Along the way, he investigates a series of murders, and brings closure to a murder he witnessed as a youth.  A well written script; a really good story.

I thought this film was, sadly, disappointing. I say this as a fan of James Lee Burke--and there's the rub: If you haven't read the Robicheaux books, you will be mystified by this film. The characters from the books are not introduced to the viewer; they simply appear--and you have no idea who they are or why they're significant to Robicheaux.

I also got very tired of Hollywood actors doing fake Louisiana accents (Tommy Lee Jones gets a pass). The requisite blues soundtrack is good. The cinematography captures the flavor of Cajun territory. But somehow it all ends up seeming contrived--like Hollywood's version of Louisiana.

Burke's books are complex, involving many, many characters and subplots, and the film tries to include everything. The end result is confusion. From one scene to the next, you're wondering exactly what is going on.

All films are obviously artificial, but good films make you forget the artifice, even those made from books (_No Country for Old Men_ comes to mind). In this film, the artifice is in your face.

Forget the movie and read the book.

In all honesty, I can't think of a better way to describe my reaction to the film other than to tell you that I logged onto Amazon tonight to purchase a copy.
I loved this film.
From the very beginning, "In the Electric Mist" draws you into an irresistible embrace and never lets go.  Every acting performance is spot-on, and the dubious culture of the Louisiana Bayou ebbs from every facet of the story.  I also need to mention the excellent soundtrack by Marco Beltrami; it is so powerful that it should be considered a character unto itself. There is a song played during the end credits that is truly one of the most beautiful songs you will ever hear.
Seriously, a great movie.
That being said, when I logged onto Amazon, I was surprised to see many reviewers voicing the opinion that this film's appeal is limited mainly to fans of the book.  It's true that "In the Electric Mist" leaves a lot to the imagination, but ambiguity and convolution are two very different things.
Take a chance.
Watch the movie.
Decide for yourself.

The Blu Ray print is BEAUTIFUL too - even in the dark interiors - but especially in the outdoor swamp shots and town houses. Disappointingly though, there are precious few extras.

Bertrand Tavernier's film isn't a masterpiece for sure, and it's perhaps just a little 'too' in love with its own gumbo and Louisiana scenery, but I found it immensely moving in places - and awkwardly real - especially on the core subject of racism and its still lingering malevolent presence (the title of this review is a rumination by one of the characters on that subject when a dead body from 1965 comes back to haunt him).

The film reminded me of John Sayles at his best ("Passion Fish" for instance) - full of heart and great observation - which is high praise indeed...

Sliding right from a short run (if that) in theatres to DVD, the excellent "In the Electric Mist" is the quintessential "sleeper" film. Based on the James Lee Burke novel "In the Electric Mist with Confederate Dead", the movie finds Burke's Cajun detective Dave Robicheaux once again hot on the trail of a brutal killer. In addition to dealing with the current killing of a young prostitute, Robicheaux must address troubling memories of a murder he witnessed more than 40 years ago as a boy. Throw in for good measure his daily grapple with alcoholism and bizarre visions of conversations with Civil War Confederate General John Bell Hood, who at best gives convoluted advice. Robicheaux (and the viewer) must decide if General Hood's presence in his life is represented by simple reveries brought on by alcohol, or a very real manifestation of the dead coming back to life in order to right a wrong. The latter assertion seems feasable, when one considers the mystical ethic of rural Louisiana where the story unfolds (focus on the last scene of the film for corroboration). Tommy Lee Jones is brilliant as the troubled, flawed, yet highly effective Robicheaux. One can't think of a better choice of actor. Filmed rather beautifully on location, director Tavernier brings the requisite "other-world" atmosphere to the table.

Watching this movie, you get the feeling that at some point it was an excellent three hour movie, but that studio suits got hold of it and bled it out. Of the modern mystery authors I've read, James Lee Burke is very possibly the most gifted. At moments his prose soars to near-poetry, his insights into humanity's greatness and smallness are impressive, as are his descriptions of the physical world his characters inhabit. "In the Electric Mist With Confederate Dead" is one of my favorite Dave Robicheaux novels, and I was pleased to learn that Tommy Lee Jones was starring in a film version of it. Unfortunately, "In the Electric Mist," as the movie is called, was a little disappoining. The script actually follows the novel very closely, and it was easy to see that Jones, the scriptwriters and director all had an affection (and respect) for the material, which I appreciated. But the movie's faithfulness to the book may have been, I think, part of the problem. There were simply too many characters and scenes in the novel to put into a less than 2-hour film for the finished product to be as effective as it might. Tommy Lee Jones turned in a fine performance as the angst-ridden, but formidable Robicheaux and John Goodman was good as Baby Feet Balboni. (I'd like to have seen more of Mary Steenburgen as Bootsie.) But while many of the scenes worked well, a number of others had an unfinished or glossed-over feel to them -- possibly the result of having to edit a little too heavily to hold down the length of the picture. Despite its flaws, however, "In the Electric Mist" was a noble effort at bringing the work of a top-drawer author together with a top-notch actor, and I salute Jones and company for making it happen. What's more, I hope they try again.

Burke's Robicheaux novels are complex, deeply evocative police thrillers set (with exceptions) in the bayou counties around New Orleans. The lead character tries to balance a deep intelligence, an unflinching commitment to justice, deep religious and family impulses, and a facility with violence which Burke presents as alternatively liberating and damning. The bayou emerges in the novels as subtle, colorful, human, a little threatening, and poised uncomfortably between a past flush with horror and a questionable, ominous future. (The stories which Burke sets in Montana deal with the geography very differently.)

This uncomfortable balance is at the heart of the Robicheaux stories, none more so than the novel on which this movie is based. At first, it's hard to imagine a less likely novel for adaptation as a Hollywood release. Burke's novels are first rate mysteries and detective stories, but they take the conventions of noir storytelling much deeper than most in his genre have done.  Given the inevitable limitation of a two hour movie in capturing the nuances available to a first-person narrator in a 300 page book, this film does an extraordinary job of capturing Robicheaux, the complexities of his character, and the haunting pull of the bayou (and southern) past which forms the background of a story of multiple murders.

Tommie Lee Jones provides an understated and utterly convincing portrait of Robicheaux, perhaps a definitive one, and he's surrounded by an extraordinary cast no less adept at economically presenting characters on both sides of the good and evil divide.

The movie is a remarkable accomplishment. It does not fully capture the book (read the book and you'll see why), but it takes the central metaphor in the book--the 'living' presence of the Confederate dead, with all that they represent--and refocuses the symbol into the presence of John Bell Hood (played beautifully by Levon Helm).  The very last scene in the film takes one further step in this refocusing, one that gilds the lily unnecessarily, but it's a forgivable and brief excess in a project which succeeds as a top-flight noir crime story, an action-adventure tale, a regional portrait, and a case study of how brilliant actors do their jobs. (In addition to Helm, by the way, the film features the great bluesman Buddy Guy.)  The movie is well worth seeing.

(I don't think the framing narrative helped.)  The ghosts who are the protectors of the life Dave grew up in show only a little of the vigor they have in the novel; the very last scene of the film, a scene that made chills run down my spine in the novel, has no punch because there's been no setup for it.

Really, a very worthy and enjoyable effort, but it does fall short.

This film marks the second time novelist James Lee Burke's Cajun detective Dave Robicheaux has been brought to film, the first being Alec Baldwin's remarkably un-Cajun version in "Heaven's Prisoners" back in 1996.  The first film was solid, but it wasn't quite the magic a series needs to launch, nor did it capture critics or audience.  This film doesn't fare much better, but not for the same reasons.

James Lee Burke's gift as a writer isn't complex mysteries, but complex characters and a poetic way of describing Louisiana country.  Only one of these gifts (cinematography) tends to resonate well in a film of what we've come to consider "average" length.  So things that propel his novels, like Dave's inner monologues, are mostly cast aside and when they do appear they come off as expositional and flat.

Another thing that works against these adaptations is their endings, which is not their fault.  Burke's villains are clear, not very mysterious, and the endings are fairly stock.  They work in the book because the book is mostly a character study of its protagonist.  When applied to these films, however, this tact feels anti-climactic.

It also bears pointing out that neither of these films features a key fun element: Dave's right-hand man Clet Purcell (a role many Burke fans thought Goodman would be perfect for), which is in keeping with their respective titles, but does lose some of the magic of better books in the series.  Neither of these books reflects the highest moments of the series overall, so they're hard-pressed to launch the films they become into the stratosphere (and in the case of In the Electric Mist, even into US. theaters).  This adapatation is also hurt by a very unlikely source: the Will Patton-read audiobooks.  Patton does such a phenomenal job capturing the tone and characterizations of Burke's world that it's hard not to see Robicheaux as Patton (who I was bucking for Hollywood to hire, but knew it was unlikely).  I kept peeking around the corners, waiting for that perfect gravely voice to lay it all out for me, but it never came.

Electric Mist has plain direction and largely feels like an homage and not an interpretation.  The director's (Bertrand Tavernier doing his first U.S. made film) love of American crime novels is no secret, but parts of this film come off as mild fan fiction:  I love me some Buddy guy, but he can't act.  Levon Helm has some pedigree, but never made his bread and butter off of acting either, and in such an understated role here, it shows.  These are vanity choices by a director enamored of American icons, not American acting.  The people in this film that can act are largely being restrained in the name of understated performances.  Even the big bad guy loses a key scene in the book where he takes a shot at Dave (batter up!) and with little else to hang his menace on, John Goodman just comes off like a storm cloud with no rain in it.  I credit the crew with largely sticking to the book and avoiding knee-jerk Hollywood-isms, like trying to explain the ethnicity of Dave's child or back track through half a dozen books for back story.

For all intents and purposes you could watch these films back-to-back and get a nice snapshot of Burke's world, even if the characterizations of the lead are vastly different.  It's interesting to see how different the acting is in roles that cross both films. Some of it is better in the first film (Badja Jola as Batist is way more engaging than Walter Breaux, and Hawthorne James is more menacing than any of the villains in Electric Mist).  Jones is a better Dave.  Mix it up and you'd have had a better film all around.

There are great movies that could be made of Burke's books.  Putting more surgical directors on the job would be a good place to start; picking the right book is a close second.  Somewhere between the moodiness of the first film and the clean lines of the second is a great adaptation worthy of launching a series.  And at this point, I'm down with Tommy Lee Jones doing it across the board.  He's got the grit and the soul, even if he does slip into typical Tommy Lee Jones stoicism a lot more than Robicheaux might warrant.  Fans of the books should check it out anyway.

This went immediately to dvd after the briefest of theatrical releases.  Fear not.  It's not a hash or a mish-mash.  It's a linear detective story that holds the attention nicely.  Based on the James Lee Burke novel, it offers some of the atmospherics that are the hallmark of Burke's art; it also has some Burkean lines thrown in for good measure.  The casting is (finally) excellent, with Tommy Lee Jones as Dave and other stalwarts like John Goodman, Ned Beatty and the wonderful Buddy Guy.  Those who are unfamiliar with the Robicheaux novels may find themselves struggling to catch up, though there are various exposition points which help fill in the blanks.  The film (like the book) includes scenes in which an LSD-doped Dave begins talking to confederate warriors (here, in particular, John Bell Hood). The Burke novels are so richly textured that the film seems somewhat lean, but it is better to attempt to capture some of the novels' atmosphere than to abandon the attempt. I consider, 'In The Electric Mist With The Confederate Dead,' released in 1993, some of the best of Burke---and his character, Robicheaux. I had the opportunity to listen to the book, way back then, on tape.  Now this was not the 'usual' audio book.  It was complete with eerie sound effects and so expertly done, that my family camped out in the living room, turned out all the lights and we made an evening out of this extraordinary tale.

While I don't believe this movie adaptation, 'In the Electric Mist, holds a candle to that first experience, it still provided a great visit, with characters that I came to love, over a decade and a half ago. It was this previous introduction that turned me on to Burke and destined me to become a loyal, forever fan.

I'm not sure why, but I've always rather envisioned Robicheaux's character to look something like the dark, craggy, and grumpy, Kinky Friedman. And in real life, he rather does. However, if given a list of potential actors, I would have placed Tommy Lee Jones on the short list, for some of the same physical characteristics. I was able to completely identify him with the role, although I could have used a tad more accent.

Robicheaux is an alcoholic, struggling to stay in remission, with many skeletons in his closet, including witnessing a black man being gunned down in the swamps, many years previously---something he chose to remain silent about.  He can no longer remain in denial, when a member of a filming crew working in the swamps, comes across the bones.  In the midst of this event, grizzly murders of prostitutes begin to take place---murders he would love to pin on his sleazy nemesis, the mobster, played by John Goodman.

The character who plays Robicheaux's daughter, Alafair, provides some nail-biting moments toward the end of the movie, as well. To digress, I've always loved the way Burke's real daughter is named Alafair and the way he sets up such a bond between Alafair and Robicheaux, in all of his work. I find this sweet and endearing.

As Robicheaux begins his investigations, he has hallucinogenic encounters with a troop of Confederate Soldiers, under the famous John Bell Hood. Hood becomes Robicheaux's ghostly sub-conscience, offering insights into seeking and finding truth---an all knowing wisdom, from the grave.

The movie is not high on budget and in some respects, it looks almost like a made for TV drama.  However, they still managed to capture the mysterious Cajun atmosphere, making you feel you might just have to start swatting skeeters. I wish there had been more development of the supernatural aspects---the war, the soldiers.  In the book and audio version, this was hair-raisingly spooky, but not so much in this movie.

There were a couple of superficial mentions of Katrina, bringing us more up to the moment with Louisiana, which felt a little out of place, because we were dealing with another place and time, with the original story.  Besides, Burke's 'The Tin Roof Blowdown,' is where he excels in describing his beloved New Orleans, post Katrina.

I agree, you don't have to have read the book to enjoy this mystery/drama. There's plenty of suspense, reminders of the devastation of war, prejudice and corruption.  It's also contemplative, ensuring we can't run from our demons; that anesthesia through alcohol, won't extinguish the omission of truth, or responsibility.

I stumbled on this treatment of James Lee Burke's "In The Electric Mist With Confederate Dead" on a Netflix order--I had not even known the movie was being filmed nor that it had been released straight to video. Being a devoted reader of everything Burke writes and particularly of his Dave Robicheaux series, I immediately ordered and viewed it.

"In The Electric Mist" gets a lot right and less wrong.  Yes the plot has holes in this version and yes, some of the characterizations will be less than fleshed out for non Burke fans.  But this is also a strength in that this film has more resonance with the poetic visions that Burke paints in his words than certainly "Heaven's Prisoners" did.

It is atmospheric and moody; indeed it was filmed in the murky depths of Louisiana parishes and bayous.  The cinematography is startling at time with wonderful panoramas of deep and textured colors that make the viewer think the scenes must be painted. The characters, whether extras in the background or featured leads, are believable and reflective of the area.  The much appreciated background music is filled with moody Cajun, blues, and zydeco sounds that again are reflective of the Louisiana milieu.

The casting was inspired from Tommy Lee Jones as Dave Robicheaux to John Goodman as a malevolent Southern mobster to Levon Helm as the Confederate General, John Bell Hood.  Mary Steenburgen does well in an underwritten role as Dave's supportive wife.  Having traveled a lot in the New Orleans and Louisiana areas, I was very satisfied with the portrayals of the characters and the places.

Lastly, the video was relatively faithful to Burke's depiction of Dave Robicheaux, especially his deep and continuing self introspection that often approaches cynicism but also ultimately values redemption of the human spirit.  Dave is portrayed with all his baggage as he struggles with his inner demons, most notably, drinking and violence.  Even with its warts, I highly recommend this effort not only to Burke/Robicheaux fans, but also to fans of Southern atmospheric mysteries and thrillers.

James Le Burke is a man who writes intense thrillers that manage to be introspective character studies and also cover the widest variety of emotions.

This film is based on one of the middle books and that may leave viewers who aren't familiar with the series a little baffled.

Dave is investigating a series of killings in the murky depths of the Louisiana bayou. The director captured the mood, tone, and scenery to the point that one can almost feel the stifling southern humidity in ones lungs while watching this.

Robicheaux has problems of his own while trying to investigate and there are many twists and turns, each one seemingly to prohibit his quest of solving these murders.

There is a whole local dynamic that further obscures the truth for him. There are cultural misunderstandings, veiled feuds, and southern racial tensions that further impede his progress.

Robicheaux also has the problem of the evil mobster, Balboni, to contend with. John Goodman's performance of the epitome of evil in this film practically stole the show for me. This role will remind people of just how talented he is.

Due to his dealings with all of the nefariousness and people who do not want him to solve the crimes, one is led through the movie wondering it Robicheaux will make it through without killing more people or being killed himself.

I know that the director could have done a better job with the suspense as compared to the book but Tommy Lee Jones' intensity, commanding performance, and the believability of the story pulled me through whatever lapses in script structure and pacing in the movie that were there. I would most strongly recommend this film to anyone who has read the books. But, if you like the great acting and those involved and the backdrop of balmy Louisiana this film will be for you too.

This is a pretty faithful adaptation of the novel, and captures the flavor of the books, as well as the Louisiana settings. In all honesty, this was almost exactly how I'd pictured it from reading the books.

But a caveat: if you haven't read the books, you're probably not going to enjoy this movie, which is probably why in the USA it was released directly to DVD. Burke's novels are very introspective, which makes for interesting literature, but slow movies. There's plenty of drama, with several murders, corruption, and depravity to spare. But the books - and this movie - are at their hearts character studies of the Robicheaux character. This is more akin to "Smilla's Sense of Snow" than "Dirty Harry".
